newsitem.title: USA: Interim nuclear waste bill unlikely - US Energy Dept.
newsitem.headline: Interim nuclear waste bill unlikely - US Energy Dept.

text.p: A senior U.S. Energy Department official Wednesday said it was unlikely that Congress would be able to pass legislation this year that would require the government to build a site for temporary storage of nuclear waste from commercial reactors.

"I think the legislation is a long shot because of the simple fact of life that you're looking at four working weeks," said Daniel Dreyfus, director of the Energy Department's Civilian Radioactive Waste Management Office.

The Senate recently passed a bill that would make the Energy Department build a temporary dump in Nevada near where the government is studying whether to build a permanent burial for highly radioactive waste from nuclear power plants.
President Clinton has repeatedly said he would veto any bill that names Nevada as the site.
While Dreyfus appeared confident that Congress would not pass the interim waste storage bill, he said that if the bill did pass his plans for developing a permanent burial site would be upset.
